column3: Excerpt From the Jungle by Upton Sinclair shows many ways the meat industry covers up and masks spoiled meat. Whether it's chemicals or a masking spray it is wrong.  The industry covered the smell by using cola or soda. "how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters;"(paragraph 2). The meat industry used soda to mask the smell and sold the meat on open counters causing more disease. Soda could have worn off and the company could have possibly be sued. The industry could have also used pickle juice or some other type of smell. "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor," ( paragraph 2). They used pickle juice to pump into the ham which was spoiled and covered up the smell. They could have possibly used another type of smell to mask the odor and this destroyed the odor. The meatpacking industry could be giving anyone spoiled meat and they would never even know.
column4: The meat industry often uses questionable methods to disguise spoiled meat. These tactics, such as chemicals, masking sprays, and the use of various other aromas, are designed to cover up the unpleasant odor associated with spoiled meat. Soda is often used as a masking agent, but its effectiveness can vary depending on the specific type of meat being treated. Despite these measures, the industry has been known to sell spoiled meat on open counters, where customers could be unknowingly exposed to hazardous toxins. The use of chemicals or masking agents can result in a variety of health risks, including illness and even death.

column3: In the text " Egyptian Social Structure " by USHistory.org, the structure of the ancient Egyptian system of goverment was structered like a pyramid . At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Osiris, and also Isis. The egyptians believed that all the gods controlled the universe, therefore it was very important to keep them happy. Egyptians also elevated some of the human biengs to gods. The pharoahs, their ledaers were also believed to be gods but in human form. Also right below the were powerful nobes and priests who where responsible for plasing the gods. Next were the  peasents, then the slaves and then there was the farmers who handled crops. In conclusion, The egyptian system of goverment has some pretty high people from gods and pharoas at the top and slaves and farmers at the bottom.
column4: The ancient Egyptian system of government resembled a pyramid, with the gods, pharaohs, nobles, priests, peasants, and slaves forming the different levels. The gods, including Ra, Osiris, and Isis, held immense power and were revered for maintaining order and prosperity. Notably, the pharaohs were believed to be gods in human form, while lower-ranking figures, such as nobles and priests, were also considered gods. The majority of the population consisted of farmers, followed by slaves and then peasants.

column3: Aristotle explains, "It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation.". By this, he means that a tragedy should make the audience feel a lot of different emotions but mostly pity and fear. They should pity the main character but also fear them because they will eventually become bad. Another element he highlights is a lapse in judgment, he writes, "— that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity,5 but by some error of judgment or frailty.". One man cannot be good nor bad but simply make a mistake. A good tragedy is when the man is just a normal person who takes the wrong turn or makes a deadly mistake that results in a series of alarming events. The final element he discusses is an unhappy ending.  Aristotle explains, "many of which end unhappily. It is, as we have said, the right ending.". Tragedies should end unhappily. The essence of a tragedy is not to get a happy ending or to have everything resolved it is just simply to end. They are very realistic pieces of literature and having a happy ending would only ruin the emotions set out throughout the entire play.
column4: Aristotle believed that tragedies should evoke a mix of emotions, encompassing both pity and fear. He noted that a tragedy should immerse the audience in a range of feelings, initially eliciting pity for the protagonist but transforming that into a sense of fear as the protagonist's misfortunes accumulate. This cyclical pattern of feelings highlights the tragic nature of the play, where the audience witnesses the protagonist's descent into darkness.Aristotle also emphasized the importance of a well-developed protagonist whose flaws contribute to the tragedy. He argued that a good tragedy usually depicts a character who is both ordinary and flawed, making a mistake that leads to a chain of unfortunate events. A tragedy should have a negative ending that emphasizes the futility of human endeavors and reinforces the idea that fate is cruel.

column3: The Third Wave experiment was created to show the students how easy it is to basically brainwash someone to fall under another's leadership. He never told them they were apart of an experiment. First explaining that he wants to eliminate democracy and gave the students rules to follow. He drills these into their heads and along with discipline. Next, he gives a simple yet catchy motto and a symbol such as a salute. Soon the students were shown how to initiate new members. The number rapidly grew from 30 to 43 to finally 200 members. Jones felt the experiment slipping away so he decided to end it. He told the student that they were apart of an experiment that showed them how easy it was to brainwash someone to do horrible things in the name of the states honor.
column4: The Third Wave experiment aimed to demonstrate the ease with which individuals could be influenced to blindly follow another person's leadership. Jones, leading the experiment, presented a clear objective—a democratic paradigm's destruction. He established a set of rules and regulations to guide the students' actions, emphasizing discipline and a clear understanding of the consequences of such practices.  Jones introduced a simple and influential motto and a distinctive symbol, a salute, to foster new member recruitment. This tactic proved highly effective, as the number of students participating in the Third Wave experiment grew rapidly. Initially, there were only 30 individuals, but this number rose to 43 and eventually reached 200 members.

column3: Throughout Sinclair's piece, he describes in great detail how the factory would go to such lengths to cover up any spoiled meat so they could profit from its sale. For instance, even the rats that ran across the meat were not spared as "there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit." This example greatly exemplified the magnitude of unsanitary items that were mixed in with the meat. Also, he employs strong diction to describe how the "moldy and white" sausage from Europe was used in conjunction with "borax and glycerin" to mask its odor, taste, and color. This again demonstrates the abysmal standards used in the meat-packing industry at the time, and further shows how the workers went to great lengths to sell the spoiled meat.
column4: Through Sinclair's meticulous description, we learn how the factory took extraordinary measures to hide spoiled meat, seeking to maximize their profit by offering it for sale. With an example of rats crossing the path of the meat, Sinclair emphasizes the vast array of unsanitary additives used to disguise the meat's true nature.  Sinclair employs powerful imagery to illustrate the grotesque process behind creating the sausage. The "moldy and white" European sausage was carefully crafted with a blend of substances that masked its odor, taste, and color. This illustrates the appalling conditions of the meat-packing industry at the time, where workers employed unethical techniques to deceive

column3: The structure of the ancient Egyptian system of government was that Egyptian society was structured like a pyramid. At the top were the gods, such as Ra, Osiris, and Isis. Egyptians believed that the gods controlled the universe. Therefore, it was important to keep them happy. They could make the Nile overflow, cause famine, or even bring death. The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods. Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form. They had absolute power over their subjects. After pharaohs died, huge stone pyramids were built as their tombs. Pharaohs were buried in chambers within the pyramids. Social classes were involved in the government since like Ancient Mesopotamia, and Ancient Egypt, they had rankings/social classes. And each have slaves, and each have gods/pharaohs.
column4: The ancient Egyptian government mirrored a hierarchical pyramid structure. At its apex were the gods—Ra, Osiris, and Isis—who were regarded as the progenitors of life. To ensure their continued favor, the Egyptians believed in the divine influence of these deities. They also elevated certain individuals to a higher plane by conferring upon them the attributes and powers associated with the gods. The pharaoh, the paramount leader, embodied divinity in human form. Absolute control was vested in the pharaohs, as they were regarded as the earthly embodiments of the gods. Massive stone structures called pyramids were built and decorated to serve as their tombs

Pharaohs, considered divine beings, were at the apex, followed by the class of vizier, who oversaw tax collection and maintained government records. Priests, tasked with aligning the gods' will, played a crucial role in maintaining order and facilitating trade throughout the civilization.

column3: One element of an ideal tragedy that is described by Aristotle is that a good tragedy should have one plot. I think this is because if there are multiple plots, there are more details and actions/events that happen. One plot really helps highlight the tragedy of one specific person or group.  A second element of an ideal tragedy is that the tragedy has to highlight the downfall of a character that readers can relate to. Relating to the character can help the readers feel more understandable of the incident that the character goes through, and because the character has to be relatable to the audience, the audience will see a little part of themselves in the character, which makes them feel pity. A third element of an ideal tragedy is that a tragedy should not resemble a comedy. A tragedy has to be serious, in order for the audience to feel fear, pity, and slight sympathy towards a character. Comedic feelings would cancel out the feelings of fear and pity which would harm the true meaning of a tragedy.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  An ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, should have one central plot focused on one person or group experiencing a tragic downfall. A relatable character, through which the audience can relate, must be at the heart of the tragedy. While a tragedy should not resemble a comedy, it must have a sense of seriousness and vulnerability to evoke fear, pity, and a sense of empathy.

column3: The first element of an ideal tragedy would be the characters. They shouldn't be too good or evil, because it wouldn't be as relatable to the viewer. They should be a middle of the road type of person pretty average but who is also respected and could have something to lose. " He must be one who is highly renowned and prosperous- a personage like Oedipus."  The second element that an ideal tragedy would be having the protagonist's luck going from good to bad. They should lose something and have something worth losing otherwise it isn't a tragedy and it shouldn't be someone else's fault that the protagonist losing everything. "The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad. It should come about as the result not of vice, but of some great error or frailty." The third element of an ideal tragedy it having the characters die, the ending needs to be sad. If you have the characters end up working everything out in the end then it can come across as a comedy. "The pleasure, however, thence derived is not the true tragic pleasure. IT is proper rather to Comedy".
column4: An ideal tragedy should feature characters that are relatable and well-developed but not outstanding or extraordinary. They should be individuals who are average in terms of both their successes and failures, with a realistic worldview and perspective.  The protagonist's journey should involve a reversal of fortune, with a significant shift from good to bad. This reversal should not be driven by malice or greed but by a tragic flaw or circumstance. The finality of the character's demise should be poignant to maintain the emotional impact of the tragedy.  An ideal tragedy should prioritize the exploration of the emotional and psychological aspects of human experience, rather than relying on superficial or overly dramatic elements.

column3: The factory would use multiple ways to cover up spoiled meat. They would rub it in soda to get rid of the sour smell, and then they would place the meat on the free counters. Also, when pickling the spoiled meat they would pump it with a stronger pickle. If the meat was consumed with mold, the factory would dose it with borax and glycerin and send it for home consumption. Spoiled sausage would be preserved with borax and colored with a dark gelatin to give it the brown smoked color. After it would be labeled as "special" and charged two cents more per pound.
column4: The factory employed several techniques to disguise spoiled meat. First, they rinsed the meat in soda to eliminate an unpleasant odor. column3: An ideal tragedy should have a complex plot. A simplistic plot would bore the audience, and not engage them enough. Creating complexity, gives the audience something that holds their attention, and in the end, could possibly shock them. Another element needed in an ideal tragedy would be a single, well-constructed plot. The fortune of the plot however should go from good to bad, resulting from an error or frailty, from a character or some other element placed within the tale. There should be a chance for the audience to feel pity or fear, that enhances the tragic moment in the plot. Overall, that would result in the plot's main goal: have the audience believing that the ending was tragic, just as a tragedy should play out.
column4: An ideal tragedy needs a layered plot that keeps the audience engaged and guessing as it unfolds. A simple plot would lose the interest and frustrate the audience. To add intrigue, the plot should have complexities and turns. Additionally, a single, well-structured plot is essential. The plot's fortune should shift from positive to negative, showcasing a character's flaws and setbacks on their journey. By creating moments of despair and fear, the tragedy should leave the audience with a profound sense of loss and tragedy. Ultimately, an ideal tragedy should inspire a sense of sorrow, just like a real tragedy
